widgets.html:
• thanks to Mikkel & Dylan/MINU festival
  • thanks to all of audience
  • introduce yourself
  • today I'm going to talk about:
    • FLOSS: Free, Libre, Open Source Software
    • what these terms actually mean
      • FLOSS tools for an art practice
    • what FLOSS could mean for an art practice
    • why I think floss is the future

• definition
    • free: as in speech, not beer
    • libre: related to above
    • open source: source code is available
      • not the same as free/libre
    • software: we will talk about non-software
  • FOSS exists

• some history
    • records of sharing information date back to automobile engine design
    • early days of computing (1950s/60s) IBM OSes
  • many people to talk about, I'll focus on:
  • Richard Stallman - responsible for:
  • GNU project in 1983
  • Free Software Foundation in 1985
  • pioneered the term Copyleft
  • has authored several free software licenses include GNU GPL
  • licenses...

• these are some tools I regularly use in my workflow:
    • SuperCollider - sound synthesis, composition
    • Open Stage Control - building controllers/instruments/slideshows
    • lilypond - notation, engraving
    • Processing - visual processing, synthesis
    • FluCoMa - machine listening, machine learning, data processing
    • flucoma demo
      • show SC in half the window?

widgets.onDraw:
ctx.fillStyle = cssVars.colorFill
ctx.globalAlpha = cssVars.alphaFillOn

var sliderWidth = width / value.length - 1
for (var i in value){
    ctx.beginPath()
    ctx.rect(i * width / value.length, height, sliderWidth, - value[i] * height)
    ctx.fill()
}

widgets.html:
• I like to code, but being a programmer is not a prerequisite for engaging with FLOSS
    • GIMP
    • vital
    • ardour
    • qlc+

• so is FLOSS so important to me and to my practice?
  • there are obvious practical reasons
    • more personal freedom as a user
    • I can actively influence the development of a tool
    • decentralizationg, democratization
    • even some of the folks at google, recognize the potential of this appraoch
    • this quote is from an leaked document wherein a Google employee reflects on the rapid development of LLMs in the wake of Meta open-sourcing their models
  • our practice is reflected in the tools we choose and the tools we choose affect how our creativity develops
  • FLOSS lets me imagine a future without limitaitons and boundaries
  • in addition, I feel FLOSS is essential for a post-capitalist practice

• using technology in new ways to articulate a radical politics -> XF
  • XF is a modern techno-/cyborgfeminism...
  • XF's three pillars according to Hester:
    • technomaterialism
    • anti-naturalism
    • gender abolistionism
  • XF calls on using technology to challenge and expand our biology
  • in a music context,I've been exploring cyborg performers w/ IEMs
  • an example from the visual arts world: Rian Ciela Hammond's Open Source Gender Codes (OSGC)
    • tobacco plants being used to synthesize human sex horomones for DIY HRT
  • projects like these demand the protection provided by FLOSS projects otherwise they can become weaponized or lead to more exploitation

• recently read an essay from 2008 by American Anthropogist David Graeber wherein he critiqued a panel discussion between four contemporary philosophers about art and labour
  • "Perhaps communism has always been with us. We are just trained not to see it. Perhaps everyday forms of communism are really...the basis for most significant forms of human achievement, even those ordinarily attributed to capitalism. If we can extricate ourselves from the shackles of fashion, the need to constantly say that whatever is happening now is necessarily unique and unprecedented...we might be able to grasp history as a field of permanent possibility, in which there is no particular reason we can't at least try to begin building a redemptive future at any time."
  • he suggests that maybe we already have the tools we need for revolution, we need to change perspective

• open source software and the communities that develop and maintain them are responsible for some of the most important technologies we have today
  • as more and more artists become techno fluent and engage with emerging technologies, our creative freedoms and political motivations have to be protected from restriction, corruption, and exploitation
  • I see open-source models as the ideal way to move forward, both with our tools, our works, and even our entire practices.
  • If this sound enticing to you, I encourage you to consider enaging with the open source ecosystem in whatever capacity you can - even GOOGLE is doing it!
  • thanks!

widgets.html:
"...the uncomfortable truth is, we aren't positioned to win this arms race and neither is OpenAI. While we've been squabbling, a third faction has been quietly eating our lunch.

I'm talking, of course, about open source. Plainly put, they are lapping us."


-Dylan Patel and Afzal Ahmad
May 4, 2023

core principles:

  • technomaterialism
    • technology as an activist tool
  • anti-naturalism
    • "extending human freedom" via biological interjection
  • gender abolitionism
    • rejects any social order "anchored in identities as a source of oppression"

"Perhaps communism has always been with us. We are just trained not to see it. Perhaps everyday forms of communism are really...the basis for most significant forms of human achievement, even those ordinarily attributed to capitalism. If we can extricate ourselves from the shackles of fashion, the need to constantly say that whatever is happening now is necessarily unique and unprecedented...we might be able to grasp history as a field of permanent possibility, in which there is no particular reason we can't at least try to begin building a redemptive future at any time."


-David Graeber
2008
